column5:
Price wise - mine was a a sliding scale. Max out of pocket was 300. 

Accuracy wise - nearly perfect for me. I only take/took what was recommended and it worked out well.

But take it with a grain of salt. Nothing is perfect, sometimes the drugs we least expect to work end up working.
Lower libido, but at least I can orgasm still. Can‚Äôt say the same for other people tho...
How are those caffeine tablets? I hate having to drink coffee to get energy.
Three months, which was a TERRIBLE idea.

There‚Äôs a theory that drugs can most certainly trigger psychosis. Your risk is elevated if you dabble in drugs while your father suffers from psychosis due to drug use.

Simply because his drug use triggered psychosis, you‚Äôd probably be in the same risk category as him.

I would avoid illicit substances.
When I was taking Wellbutrin, I had it combined with Prozac. Was a good combo until the Wellbutrin pooped out on me and started to make me straight up anxious, so I quit it. Still take the Prozac.

From my personal experience, Wellbutrin anxiety isn‚Äôt the anxiety that disappears as your body adjusts. I would talk to your doc about dropping down a dose. If you keep taking it, it‚Äôll keep happening.

Personally, I felt that crushing anxiety at 150mg and I unwisely kept taking it. Talk about anxiety, I was a ball of stress.
Please tell your doctor. New hallucinations can be serious, especially if they‚Äôre scary.
I only got over my fear of needles after being in the ward for a while. They took my blood every morning since I was on lithium. Fun times. What a way to get over a fear.

I took a genesight test a few years ago and got back results that really helped me. Not sure if it helped you, but the drugs were spot on. I have a younger sister who took the same test (different condition [my schizophrenia vs. her depression]). We came up with totally different drugs and reactions to folic acid/folate. I have an under reaction. So I was recommended for a supplement.

I don‚Äôt take one. My meds that were recommended for me on the test work well enough.

Think of it as you‚Äôre a diabetic and you need insulin.

Would you stop taking the insulin because it made you feel better? Even if stopping means a return to your previous state?

I mean, you could taper off and be free of it, but many people relapse with their depression after quitting their meds, simply because the medicine was working on whatever was off in your brain.

Just food for thought. I wouldn‚Äôt stop, and I have stopped meds and paid the price for it.

There are long term ‚Äúasylums‚Äù for the mentally ill still. 

I have the privilege to work at a short-stay facility. The average time of treatment is two weeks. They come in during a crisis (Usually suicidal or aggressive), receive med tweaks, get their wounds sewed up, talk to counselors nurses and social workers, then are released back into the world, usually on a partial hospitalization plan.

Larger state hospitals can keep people for years, even lifetimes. Folks average about 1-2 years in the care of these hospitals. They are the more ‚Äúchronic‚Äù cases, where there is often no cure nor long term management. Some patients refuse medication, others are simply too far gone for therapies to make a dent. These hospitals are ultimately more depressing in my opinion, as rates of wellness and return to society are low.

Hi, previously diagnosed bipolar 1, now diagnosed schizoaffective bipolar type.

I can relate to the terrible mood swings. I remember rapid cycling between sobbing on the floor and singing really loud and having tons of sex. Day and night. Terrible way to be.

Insomnia plagued me. And the only thing that helped was mirtazapine. Total life saver. Once I got sleep the cycling slowed down, then they put me on lithium to finish it off. Another life saver. 

The problem with drugs is that there are so many of them and they all affect us differently. You might need to change your medication, which is unfortunately all to common in the world of mental health.
I had a delusion where My arms weren‚Äôt mine and I tried to cut them off. Really fucked up one shoulder. I‚Äôm thankful the scars healed well.

As someone who was cut the majority of their skin, try your hardest to resist, please. I‚Äôm lucky my arms and legs healed, but my breast, stomach and pubic area are covered in hard scars. 

Those are only seen when I‚Äôm intimate with someone, which is embarrassing. If you keep cutting, keep it in one place.

I would talk to a doctor about whenever or not he should take the propranolol with the Zoloft. It‚Äôs a safe combo (I take propranolol and Prozac, among other drugs). But, the doctor might want to stop the propranolol just to see if the Zoloft is effective. Plus, those side effects sound a bit much for propranolol. Consult your doc.
No joke, just had a random call from a guy I'm seeing. The conversation literally consisted of him crying about feeling trapped indoors away from friends. Felt like saying "that's my every day life."
Sometimes docs prescribe Wellbutrin with SSRI/SNRI drugs to prevent this. That could be a possible alternative for you instead of switching meds.
10mg isn‚Äôt a therapeutic dose. 20mg is considered the starting dose for Prozac. Talk to your psych doc about upping it and see how you feel from there. That should given you a more accurate result.

It never hurts to talk to your doctor about this stuff. APs are known for their side effects, and they are pretty unpleasant.

Abilify made me nauseous too, so I took it with food, that seemed to eliminate reflux and nausea. But you should talk to your your doc about things like headaches and drowsiness. Just to see what they think you should continue doing.
I love this! I had a bracelet once that I lost, wish i could find it because i think it's a good idea for those with this disorder to have something just in case something goes wild in our heads.

Okay so I take both a typical (Prolixin) and an atypical (Latuda). Together they work well to control my hallucinations and delusions. Latuda focuses more on mood disruption, while Prolixin is purely for positive symptoms of schizophrenia.

The only problem with typicals are the Tardive Dyskinesia side effects - you‚Äôre more likely to get them on the old typical than the new atypicals.

PPD and PPP (Postpartum psychosis) are very real things, all caused by birth and hormonal fluctuations.

My advice is to see your PCP or psychiatrist, and see what they have to say. We can‚Äôt diagnose through here, but they certainly can. Plus, if you were taking meds before, now might be a good time to start up with some baby-safe medicine (if you‚Äôre breastfeeding).
Glad you found a drug that works for you! I take Prozac as well, and I give it credit for pulling me out of my depressive episodes.

I‚Äôve been hospitalized four times, committed twice. I‚Äôm now a psych nurse working in a long term ward.

The routines change depending on  the hospital you‚Äôre at.

They take away anything with laces, ropes, spirals, anything. These are suicide hazards. They take your hight, weight, vitals, and quiz you on your symptoms. Then they search your body. Usually this is to identify self inflicted wounds or anything else that can help us understand why that patient needs help.

Pack a bag with clothes. Remember, no laces. Bring socks, or they will give you hospital socks (which I love but not everyone does).

Write down phone numbers, you will probably lose access to your phone while you‚Äôre there.

Am a psych nurse in an inpatient setting. Everyone‚Äôs wearing masks, and we had one patient with a fever that we quarantined in their room. Admissions are vetted and we aren‚Äôt allowing anyone else with a fever in our building, patient or staff.

Me personally - I‚Äôm also a psych patient. I‚Äôve been so anxious about working that it‚Äôs driving me up a wall.
As a psychiatric nurse, we consider this self harm. So yes, it is.
I like this brand. I know the other post wasn't received as well. I'm hoping this one will be seen in a better life, because it's a motto to live by.

Moclobemide is a MAOI antidepressant, and it isn't prescribed in the US so I don't know much about it, other than the dietary restrictions you must be aware of when you take it. 

If it isn't working a couple of months in, then you either need a dose increase or to try another drug.
My parents found out after my first admittance to a psych ward. Immediately got all threatening and aggressive with me. "Why would you be so weak and stupid?"

Personally, I think a low dose antidepressant could be helpful, especially if you're diagnosed with depression.

People like to rag on the pills, but think of it like this - if you were diabetic, would you avoid insulin even though your body is either resistant to it or does not produce it enough?

Feel free to ask my opinions on meds, I've taken a lot and have now had found one that works for me.

My doc put me on vyvanse for weight loss (plus managing my AHDH symptoms).

It helped me lose around 30 lbs. Which was fantastic and the first weight I've lost since starting my cocktail meds.
Im so proud of you! As a fellow schizophrenic working with the mentally unwell children, it‚Äôs so worth being there for young ones when you didn‚Äôt have that for yourself at their age.

I can‚Äôt function without medication. I was a nightmare without it. Diagnosed in 2018, put on Abilify, and let go from the psych ward.

I take Latuda and Prolixin now, both are awesome for me.

Lexapro did the same thing to me too. I thought I was broke for good. 

Then I went off it (switched to another med) and my sex drive/libido/ability to climax improved.

It can take 4-6 weeks (and in some cases, a wee bit longer) for you to feel the antidepressant acting on your emotions.

I take both mirtazapine and Prozac, and both took about a month to show results.
Alright, I‚Äôll admit it, you got me good.
Your story is similar to mine. I remember those days. Psych wards are interesting places.

I take Vyvanse and Adderall for my ADHD, and I believe both help me with more than just the ADHD. To simply put it, I feel more focused energy, which in turn makes me more likely to be active and functioning during the day. I'm able to wake up in a depressed fog, take my meds, and feel better within the hour.

I‚Äôm sorry you haven‚Äôt found an antipsychotic that doesn‚Äôt cause you weight gain.

It‚Äôs unfortunate - everyone has a different metabolism and that can affect how we process these drugs, and how much they affect us.

In my experience, Latuda has been largely weight neutral for me. I take the max dose and haven‚Äôt gained anything while on it. In addition to that, my secondary antipsychotic Prolixin (which is an old drug) is also weight neutral for me, and I haven‚Äôt gained anything while on it.

Hope this helps. I‚Äôve taken a few different ones, so if you have any more questions, feel free to ask.
A low dose of Latuda might not be enough for you to reduce your hallucinations. It wasn‚Äôt for me.
It feels like shouting into a void for me, that‚Äôs basically what this is üòÇ

I've tried a lot of anti-psychotics, many of them cause that hunger and weight gain. if you want, feel free to message me and I'll give you my honest opinion on some of the drugs I've taken, as well as others I've done research on.
No need to apologize! She‚Äôll be a happy to know someone called her pretty!
Thank you!
Not me, sorry shoulda made that  clear. It‚Äôs one of my models. But I will agree. She‚Äôs beautiful.

Had an old friend disappear for weeks. He was heavily involved in my hobbies community (photography).

Deleted his pictures on Instagram - his professional stuff. And began posting again. But this time, it was this picture, followed by an ad for the Primerica MLM company.

Good to see he replaced a fun hobby/profession for that. üôÑ

Hey, I‚Äôm sorry you‚Äôre having a rough go at it.

This behavioral pattern mirrors something called borderline personality disorder.

I‚Äôm not diagnosing you. But maybe you should talk to a therapist or psychiatrist about the reasons behind your self harm habit. They can get you the help you need.

To answer both your questions - 1. I‚Äôm not a doctor, but a psychiatric nurse. I also personally have a mental disorder. What you‚Äôve described sounds like depression to me, or at least some form of low mood.

2. Medicine can be prescribed by any doctor, but to really understand and get to the root of your issue, you may need to see a psychiatrist. They specialize in brain function and brain drugs.

If you have any questions, shoot me a message. I‚Äôve been doing this for a long time.

Vyvanse and Adderall have both been great helps for my ADHD and cognitive issues. 

I‚Äôm a little bummed for you - that lady sounds irresponsible. My doc was so on board with treating my ADHD with whatever works for me. I‚Äôm happy you plan on seeing someone else.

I say, preface the conversation with a ‚ÄúI used to take Vyvanse, and that helped a lot.‚Äù Any doc worth their salt will accept that. 

I hate being treated like a drug seeker. Bitch I just want what works for me...

My experience with this drug was negative - it made me incredibly drowsy. Like way more than any drug I‚Äôve ever tried.
That doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôll have the same experience. It works for a lot of people.
I‚Äôm schizoaffective bipolar type, I‚Äôve had a fair bit of experience with this disorder, shoot me a dm
I don‚Äôt see why he‚Äôs jumping right to Lyrica (which is from what I hear a hard drug to get used to).
No waaay, off to do research
The PRNs I have listed are Ativan, adderall, and Prolixin!

That‚Äôs basically what TD is, along with facial/neck twitching, tongue movements, etc.

Edit - sorry, TD stands for tardive dyskinesia.
Its BRAND new, like I‚Äôm not even sure if it‚Äôs available yet.
I actually take cogentin because another drug I took gave me TD. My Prolixin doesn‚Äôt give me any side effects thankfully.
Cogentin is my only drug for side effects. And that‚Äôs because another drug gave me TD. Which doesn‚Äôt go away.
Im a woman.
Who knew a post about what helps me would rub so many people the wrong way. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
The ‚Äúpoison‚Äù seems to make me feel better with it than without it, it seems.
I have to take two for my hallucinations.

One for mood management, one for ptsd related nightmares, two for physical anxiety, Two for ADHD, two for hallucinations, one for sleep, and one for depression.

Not everyone‚Äôs treatment is the same.
I agree, this many meds isn‚Äôt okay. But we all fight our battles differently.
Yeah they have 600mg capsules. I originally started at 300mg 2x a day as well. I was on board with making the switch to a 600mg pill because of the sheer amount of pills I had in each hand every day.

Hope you‚Äôre well too!

Yeah this global pandemic is doing some damage to everyone‚Äôs mental health.

Hi! Here‚Äôs my list

AM:

Lithium 600mg

Yikes, hair falling out is not good at all.
Seroquel and me don‚Äôt get along well either. Sedated me waaaayyy too much, and cause my cholesterol to increase dramatically.
Happy dreams are worth it! Mine aren‚Äôt so kind to me. I wish they were.

Yes thyroid is a concern of mine as well. They check those with the blood draws. So far so good for me. 

Never taken tegretol. Most certainly have heard of it. Have you tried anything else other than lithium? Best to reserve that for emergencies in my opinion.

No bother at all! I like discussing this stuff. 

Lithium has been a great help to me, as every other mood stabilizer has been a nightmare (lamictal gave me rashes, depakote knocked me out for days, gabapentin made me dizzy and uncomfortable).

They usually use lithium as a emergency/quick mood stabilizer. This is because it acts so quickly in the body. But this comes at a price - I get my blood drawn quite frequently in order to monitor levels. Also, I pee a lot now. And drink lots of water. My mouth gets dry.
Mine takes away all my dreams, which I‚Äôm happy with. My dreams suck.
PRN means I take it as needed. Sorry, shoulda made that clear üôÇ
I have schizoaffective bipolar type, ADHD, GAD, and CPTSD. My condition is severe enough to warrant the meds. One day I‚Äôll be down to less than this, I hope.
Prazosin seems to change appearances every time I pick up a new bottle! My old pill was brown and green. The new one is an off white/yellowish color.
Yeah! Helps with the concentration and the ADHD.

Thanks for the support guys, I appreciate it. I don‚Äôt LOVE taking them, but they‚Äôre needed. So I appreciate what they do for me in keeping me sane.

Personally, trazodone didn‚Äôt do much for me. It was very similar to your experience so far.
Only thing that helped my insomnia was mirtazapine.
My doc always says one day I‚Äôll be down to a med or two. But for now, my brain is scrambled. I‚Äôm glad they help me tho.
Yes, they absolutely are. I‚Äôve never felt as good as I do now and that‚Äôs saying something.
Switched from lexapro to Prozac two years ago. Made huge dents in my anxiety and panic disorders.
It‚Äôs safe. Been taking it for two years with no side effects. Worked well for my GAD and panic, as well as my depression.
What‚Äôs the proof?
Easily 8-9. My delusions started younger, but I didn‚Äôt hear voices until then.
Yes. I‚Äôm on a max dose of Latuda (and a small dose of Prolixin). I still get small voice hallucinations.
True mania is life-altering. I know not everyone likes meds, but some things mania (or dysphoria) makes us do shout indicate our need for these substances.
You should get stitches even if it doesn‚Äôt continue bleeding, especially if it‚Äôs a wide, deep cut. Clean it well and seek medical attention.
It took me about six to seven weeks to feel it. The usual duration is 6-8 weeks
Most certainly was a problem. Prozac helped immensely. It‚Äôs my only med that handles anxiety like a champ.
Trust me, I DON‚ÄôT handle it. At all. Gets me into some... sticky situations.

Hey, I get it. Taking that first step into the medicated world is scary. You feel ashamed to admit that you need help. It‚Äôs not a bad thing to be turned off by medication.

What you have to understand is that the feeling of emptiness you have is depression. A physiological condition of the brain. That‚Äôs how most depression appears in people - a void. It‚Äôs not all crying and sadness. Most of the time, it‚Äôs just emptiness. 

You‚Äôll probably hear this comparison a lot. What if you were a diabetic and needed insulin because your body doesn‚Äôt produce it. Would you refuse that chemical because it‚Äôs not your ‚Äúofficial‚Äù chemical? Meds are designed to give us what we don‚Äôt have or take away something we have too much of. Usually that‚Äôs serotonin, norepinephrine, or dopamine.

 Give the meds a shot. Let them do what they‚Äôre designed to do. 
.
I‚Äôm not even going to entertain the stupidity of your comments. You sound like a WONDERFUL person to be around.
I‚Äôm taking 40mg capsules!

I haven‚Äôt switched from Paxil to Prozac. But I had switched from lexapro to Prozac.
It was an okay switch. Didn‚Äôt really feel much, other than happier. Prozac works well for me.

1 - they are usually prescribed by a psychiatrist or a medical doctor/nurse practitioner. They listen to you explain how you feel, they can run tests, get to know you, then deem whether or not you need a med.

2 - they can only see what‚Äôs in your system if they drug test you. And that only really works with drugs that people can check for (like illicit drugs or schedule 1 drugs). Generally, they won‚Äôt test for prescribed meds unless they‚Äôre an abuse risk.
I would agree that being home now would be a great time to text out new meds. Give it a shot!

Hi! A known side effect of some SSRIs is psychical anxiety. Like teeth chattering and leg pain/cramps. This might go away once you get used to the new med. If not, you can always try another. Don‚Äôt feel too disheartened, there‚Äôs a plethora of options available to you.
